citations.original: W.J. Hehre, R. Ditchfield and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 56,
2257 (1972).  Note: Li and B come from J.D. Dill and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 62, 2921 (1975).
M.M. Francl, W.J. Petro, W.J. Hehre, J.S. Binkley, M.S. Gordon, D.J. DeFrees and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 77, 3654 (1982)
V. Rassolov, J.A. Pople, M. Ratner and T.L. Windus, J. Chem. Phys. 109, 1223 (1998)
He and Ne are unpublished basis sets taken from the Gaussian program  Polarization functions ----------------------
P.C. Hariharan and J.A. Pople, Theoret. Chimica Acta 28, 213 (1973).
M.M. Francl, W.J. Petro, W.J. Hehre, J.S. Binkley, M.S. Gordon, D.J. DeFrees and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 77, 3654 (1982).
V. Rassolov, J.A. Pople, M. Ratner and T.L. Windus, J. Chem. Phys. 109, 1223 (1998)
He and Ne are unpublished basis sets taken from Gaussian.  Pople-style Diffuse Functions ------------------------------ Elements                    References
(1s)     T. Clark, J. Chandrasekhar, G.W. Spitznagel and P. von R.

(1s,1p)  R. Krishnam, J.S. Binkley, R. Seeger, J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 72, 650 (1980). P.M.W. Gill, B.G. Johnson, J.A. Pople and M.J. Frisch, Chem. Phys. Lett. 197, 499 (1992). These exponents were optimized for 8 small anions using the 3-21G basis set at the HF level of theory by Clark et al.  Frisch, Pople and Binkley reoptimized the exponents at the MP4 level for both neutral and anionic systems.  The (s,p) sets employ shared exponents for better integral speed.

original:
Elements                             References
--------                             ----------
H - He: W.J. Hehre, R. Ditchfield and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 56,
Li - Ne: 2257 (1972).  Note: Li and B come from J.D. Dill and J.A.
Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 62, 2921 (1975).
Na - Ar: M.M. Francl, W.J. Petro, W.J. Hehre, J.S. Binkley, M.S. Gordon,
D.J. DeFrees and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 77, 3654 (1982)
K  - Zn: V. Rassolov, J.A. Pople, M. Ratner and T.L. Windus, J. Chem. Phys.
109, 1223 (1998)
Note: He and Ne are unpublished basis sets taken from the Gaussian
program

Polarization functions
----------------------
Li - Ne: P.C. Hariharan and J.A. Pople, Theoret. Chimica Acta 28, 213 (1973).
Na - Ar: M.M. Francl, W.J. Petro, W.J. Hehre, J.S. Binkley, M.S. Gordon, D.J.
DeFrees and J.A. Pople, J. Chem. Phys. 77, 3654 (1982).
K  - Zn: V. Rassolov, J.A. Pople, M. Ratner and T.L. Windus, J. Chem. Phys.
109, 1223 (1998)

Note: He and Ne are unpublished basis sets taken from Gaussian.

Pople-style Diffuse Functions
------------------------------
Elements                    References
H: (1s)     T. Clark, J. Chandrasekhar, G.W. Spitznagel and P. von R.
Li - Ne: (1s,1p)  Schleyer. J. Comp. Chem. 4, 294 (1983).
Na - Ar: (1s,1p)  R. Krishnam, J.S. Binkley, R. Seeger, J.A. Pople,
J. Chem. Phys. 72, 650 (1980).
P.M.W. Gill, B.G. Johnson, J.A. Pople and M.J. Frisch,
Chem. Phys. Lett. 197, 499 (1992).
These exponents were optimized for 8 small anions using the 3-21G basis set at
the HF level of theory by Clark et al.  Frisch, Pople and Binkley reoptimized
the exponents at the MP4 level for both neutral and anionic systems.  The
(s,p) sets employ shared exponents for better integral speed.
